text: - Hello, everyone, my name is Pooja Gupta,

I work as Associate
Solution Architect at AWS.

Today, we are going to talk
about Amazon Q in QuickSight.

Amazon Q in QuickSight
enhances business productivity
with generative BI capabilities
to accelerate decision making.
With help of QuickSight Q,
you can build dashboards in minutes,

get actionable insights
at your fingertips,
and create and share rich data stories,

all of this using natural
language processing.
Let us now have a look at the Amazon Q
in QuickSight on the console.
We will start our demo now.
As a first step, we need

to create a new data
set within QuickSight.
We'll click on this button,

and as we can see, we
have multiple options

to import our data from
such as RDS, Redshift,
S3, Athena, and many more.
For this demo purposes, we'll be using S3
to import our data.
We can see that within S3,

I've already uploaded a
data set as a CSV file.
We will select this S3 option

and provide a data source
name as per our choice.

You'll see that this will also
ask us for a manifest file.
Manifest file is nothing but adjacent file

containing the file
format, the file location,
and things like file delimiter.

Once we have uploaded it,
we can click on connect,
and our data set will be ready to preview.
I've already created a sample dataset

and this is how it looks
after everything is ready.
We can click on edit dataset

to view the list of fields
that have been imported

to QuickSight and also the
data that has been imported.
Since a dataset is now ready,
let us try to build some visuals.
We will click on publish and visualize
and then click on create.
This will create the analysis for us.
We can start by manually creating a chart,

by selecting the visual
type, selecting the group,

the value from the options
that are present here
as part of our data set.
We see that a pie chart is created,

which shows the number of units
sold per product category.

We can also leverage
natural language processing
to build some charts.

For that, we'll click
on this build button,

and we'll provide a
prompt in simple English.

For example, I've given a
prompt to create a bar graph,
showing revenue per month for our sales.

However, if you notice, we
do not have any month field
as part of a data set.

So for that, let's click
on calculated field
and try to create a month field.

We can, again, leverage Q to
create the month field for us

without having the need
to remember the syntax.
So we'll type calculate the month
from date field and click on build.
This will create the syntax for us,
which we can simply insert into our code.

And here we go. Once we
save it, it'll validate

and the month field is added
as part of our data set now.
We'll continue building the visual
and we'll paste the prompt again,
which says to build a bar graph,

showing the revenue per
month for our sales,
and click on build.
It takes few seconds to get uploaded,
and then we'll see a bar graph is created.
We can edit this bar graph if you want.

I'm happy with this, so I'll
simply add it to analysis.
Once this is added to analysis,

we can actually publish
this to create a dashboard.

A dashboard is a collection of
charts, graphs, and insights.

You can share these dashboards
with your target audience

and can also set schedules
to automate sharing.
Let's go ahead and give this a name.
Let's call it SalesDbDashboard,
and click on publish dashboard.

It'll take few seconds to
generate the dashboard.

And now, you can share this
dashboard by clicking on this

and click on schedules
to automate your sharing.

And you can also click on
this icon to set alerts.
We have our dashboard ready,

but what if user wants
to get a specific insight
by asking queries in simple English?

With the help of QuickSight
Q topics, we'll be able

to leverage Gen BI
capabilities to do the same.
QuickSight Q topics help us create, store,

and maintain data with maintaining
an index with definition.
So let's try and click on new topic.
We can give a name such as demo topic,

give a brief if required,
otherwise you can skip this,
and then we'll select a data set.

For instance, we can
select data sales too,
and click on create.

For this demo purpose, I've
already created a topic,

and let's go ahead and see
how a topic looks like.

If we click on the data
section, we'll be able to see
that all fields are mentioned here,

and there are some synonyms
that can be used in the queries

that we ask using natural
language processing.

For that, we'll click
on this question button,
ask a question, and ask a question.
So let's ask, what is the product
with highest units sold?
And once we ask this, we'll be able
to see two Gen BI capabilities
where we'll get a multi-visual response.
This might give us graph, as you can see,
also a tabular form,
which mentions Hanes Comfort Soft T-shirt
has the maximum unit sold.

And also, it has given an
answer in simple English,
saying, the top selling product

is the Hanes Comfort Soft
T-shirt with 10 units sold.
Lastly, AWS also understands

that business users spend a
lot of time extracting data

and insights from dashboard
to create presentation
for their stakeholders.

The new stories feature
that QuickSight provides
helps business users interpret data
and share insights.
We can add visuals from the ones

that we had previously
created and then give a prompt
such as create a sales report showing
the growth of sales over months

and how different product
categories performed
in terms of units sold.

Once ready, we'll click
on the build button.
It takes few seconds to generate,
so I've already created one for you.
And we see that Q has utilized
artificial intelligence capabilities
to gather the context from a prompt
and give an appropriate heading

as well as give appropriate
sections included in the report.
We see that the graphs have been included

and there is a proper
analysis done for the graph.

So this is how you can
create data stories.
And that's all for today's video.

Hope you enjoyed it, and
thank you for listening.
